transcript:
Therapist: You've done a great job with the thought record, Liam. Now, let's discuss the behavioral experiment we planned last session, where you would send out a certain number of job applications and track the responses. Were you able to complete this experiment?

Patient: Yes, I sent out 10 applications over the past week. I haven't heard back from any of them yet, but I've been trying to manage my expectations and not jump to negative conclusions.

Therapist: That's excellent, Liam. Even though you haven't received any responses yet, this experiment can still provide us with valuable information. Let's look at the predictions you made before starting the experiment. What were some of your thoughts about the outcome?

Patient: I predicted that I wouldn't get any interviews or job offers because I'm not qualified enough. I also thought that if I didn't get any responses, it would confirm that I'm a failure and that I'll never find a job.

Therapist: Thank you for sharing those predictions, Liam. Now, let's examine the evidence from the experiment so far. You mentioned that you haven't received any responses yet. Is there any evidence that contradicts your prediction that you're not qualified enough?

Patient: Well, I haven't received any outright rejections yet, so I suppose that's a good sign. And when I look at the job requirements, I do meet most of them, even if I don't have 100% of the desired qualifications.

Therapist: That's an important observation, Liam. It's common for job seekers to underestimate their qualifications and assume the worst when they don't hear back immediately. The fact that you haven't received rejections and that you meet most of the requirements suggests that you are indeed qualified for these positions. What about your prediction that not getting responses would mean you're a failure and that you'll never find a job?

Patient: I guess I'm starting to see that my worth isn't solely determined by whether I get these specific jobs. It's a competitive market, and there are many factors at play. Just because I haven't found the right fit yet doesn't mean I'm a failure or that I'll never find a job.

Therapist: That's a significant insight, Liam. You're challenging the cognitive distortion of catastrophizing, where you're assuming the worst-case scenario based on limited information. By recognizing that your worth isn't tied to the outcome of these applications and that there are many factors involved, you're developing a more balanced and realistic perspective. How does this new understanding make you feel about your job search?

Patient: It definitely takes some of the pressure off. I'm starting to see that it's a process, and it might take time to find the right opportunity. I don't have to define myself by the outcome of each application.

Therapist: That's a healthy and adaptive mindset, Liam. As we continue with this behavioral experiment, I encourage you to keep tracking your applications and responses, and to challenge any negative thoughts that arise using the techniques we've discussed. Remember, each application is an opportunity to gather more evidence and refine your approach.

Patient: I'll keep that in mind. It's helpful to see the job search as an experiment rather than a reflection of my worth.

Therapist: You're making excellent progress, Liam. Now, let's revisit the worry time technique we discussed last session. Have you been able to implement this technique, and if so, how has it been working for you?

Patient: I've been trying to use the worry time technique, but I've found it challenging to stick to the designated time. I often find myself worrying outside of the scheduled time, especially when I'm feeling anxious about my job search or other stressors.

Therapist: That's a common challenge, Liam. It takes practice to train our minds to postpone worries until the designated time. One strategy that can help is to create a physical "worry list" where you write down your worries as they arise throughout the day. This can help you feel more in control of your thoughts and reassure yourself that you will address them during your worry time. During your worry time, you can review the list and use the thought record techniques to challenge any distorted thoughts.
